questions.question: Question 1: What is the most common gene mutation associated with hemochromatosis?
questions.explanation:
The most common mutation seen in hemochromatosis is a cysteine to tyrosine substitution at 
position 282 (C282Y) in the HFE gene. HFE mutations are the most common cause of hereditary hemochromatosis and are inherited as 
an autosomal recessive trait.

questions.question: Question 2: Patients with which of the following conditions are unlikely to develop iron overload?
questions.explanation:
Thalassemia minor does not result in iron overload. Secondary hemochromatosis or iron overload 
is characterized by the deposition of iron in parenchymal cells.

questions.question:
Question 3: Which of the following clinical manifestations of hemochromatosis is incorrectly matched 
with its mechanism of onset?
questions.explanation:
Sexual dysfunction (decreased libido, impotence, amenorrhea) in hemochromatosis occurs as a 
result of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. This is due to iron deposition in the pituitary gland, 
not testes. 321

questions.question:
Question 4: A 7-year-old boy undergoes genetic testing as his brother has been diagnosed with hereditary 
hemochromatosis. He is found to be homozygous for the C282Y mutation. Which of the 
following is the strongest indicator that he will develop symptoms of the disease?
questions.explanation:
Serum ferritin > 1000 g/L is the strongest predictor of disease expression among individuals 
homozygous for the C282Y mutation. Many patients with C282Y mutations are initially asymptomatic and do not show features of iron 
overload. In such patients, serum ferritin can indicate whether they are likely to develop the 
disease as ferritin levels reflect the total iron stores. As ferritin levels may be high following inflammatory conditions, combined measurement of 
ferritin and transferrin saturation is done in a practical setting to avoid false positives. It is also 
repeated once inflammation subsides. If these tests are abnormal, genetic testing for HFE 
mutations is done.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 47-year-old diabetic man is worried as the skin over his face, neck, and dorsum of hands 
has turned greyish over the past two months. He also complains of abdominal and joint pain. 
On examination, gynecomastia and hepatomegaly are noted. What is the treatment of choice 
for this condition?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of hemochromatosis. The treatment of choice is the removal of 
excess iron by phlebotomy. Phlebotomy is an inexpensive, convenient, and safe method of treatment. In this process, 500 mL 
of blood is removed 1-2 times weekly which removes 200-250 mg of iron. Weekly phlebotomy 
should be continued until the serum ferritin level is 100 g/L and every 3 months thereafter. It is 
contraindicated in severe anemia and hypoproteinemia. Chelating agents bind to iron to form complexes that get excreted and are the drugs of choice. 
Drugs such as deferoxamine and deferasirox are commonly used. However, they are less effective 322 
Sold by @itachibot and more expensive than phlebotomy. Liver transplantation is indicated either in end-stage liver disease or in refractory cases. Supportive management includes avoiding iron-containing substances such as red meat, 
multi-vitamin tablets, etc. Alcohol should be completely avoided as it can aggravate the disease.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 30-year-old man with hereditary hemochromatosis has been started on weekly phlebotomy. 
All of the following features will improve with this treatment except:
questions.explanation:
In hemochromatosis, removal of excess iron through phlebotomy has no effect on arthropathy 
and hypogonadism.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is incorrect about Wilson's disease?

options.b: AP1S1 gene is essential for normal functioning
options.c: Siblings of affected children have 1 in 4 risk of the disease

questions.explanation:
Wilson’s disease is caused due to a loss-of-function mutation in the ATP7B gene on Chr.13q. The 
gene encodes a copper transporting ATPase (ATP7B) which has 2 functions: • Maintains copper in bound form by binding copper to apoceruloplasmin • Helps excrete free copper in bile. Thus, an ATP7B deficiency leads to excess deposition of free copper within tissues. It is an 
autosomal recessive condition. So, siblings of affected children have a 1 in 4 chance. Intracellular trafficking of ATP7B (Wilson's disease) and ATP7A (Menke's disease) genes are 
regulated by an adaptor protein encoded by the AP1S1 gene. Mutations in this gene result in a 
syndrome with features of both Wilson's and Menke's diseases. It is called MEDNIK syndrome: • Mental retardation • Enteropathy • Deafness • Neuropathy • Ichthyosis • Keratodermia.

questions.question:
Question 8: 316 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following are true regarding KF ring?
questions.explanation:
Among the given options only statements 1 and 5 are true. Kayser-Fleischer (KF) rings are seen in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological 
involvement. It initially appears as a crescent in the superior pole of Descemet's membrane and 
gradually extends inferiorly, eventually becoming circumferential in shape. KF rings occur due to copper deposition in the descemet's membrane. It is golden-brown to 
greenish-brown in color and can be best seen by slit-lamp examination. 323 
Sold by @itachibot The image below shows a KF ring : While it is a characteristic sign of Wilson’s disease (statement 2), it can also be seen in: • Primary biliary cholangitis • Primary sclerosing cholangitis • Cholestasis KF rings are present in almost 95% of patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric 
symptoms compared to around 65% of those with hepatic presentations (statement 4). They disappear on treatment with copper-chelating agents like d-penicillamine (while 
desferrioxamine is an iron chelating agent) and reappear with disease progression (statement 3).

questions.question: Question 9: In patients with Wilson's disease, Kayser-Fleischer rings are most commonly associated with:
questions.explanation:
The presence of the Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring in Wilson's disease is most commonly associated 
with neuropsychiatric manifestations such as dystonia. In majority of the cases, neuropsychiatric manifestations follow hepatic manifestations. It is due 
to the deposition of free copper in the basal ganglia (leading to bilateral degeneration and 
atrophy) and cortex. The features include: • Dysarthria (most common): Irregular word spacing, hypophonic or spastic speech • Dystonia: Vacuous smile i.e mask-like face with an open mouth • Parkinsonism: Bradykinesia, postural instability, rigidity • Subcortical dementia: Slow mental processing, memory loss • Psychiatric symptoms: Loss of emotional control, depression, hyperactivity • Decreased scholastic performance: Deterioration in handwriting, clumsiness • Autonomic symptoms: Excessive sweating and salivation, sexual dysfunction 324 
Sold by @itachibot • Wing beating tremors (seen in advanced disease): High amplitude tremor that is prominent with 
arms abducted, elbows flexed and palms facing downward.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 22-year-old woman is being evaluated in the emergency department for a 3-day history of 
dark-colored urine and abdominal distension. On examination, she is conscious and oriented. 
Icterus is present. The following investigations are done. Which of the following would you 
suspect?
questions.explanation:
The given laboratory values indicate hepatic disease and hemolytic anemia (low Hb with high 
reticulocyte count). These lab findings along with clinical features point to a diagnosis of Wilson's 
disease. The clinical features of Wilson’s disease include: Option A: Hemochromatosis presents with clinical features of iron overload. Serum ferritin and 
total iron are elevated. Option B: Acute viral hepatitis presents with positive HbsAg, whereas anti-Hbs IgG indicates past 
infection. There is tender hepatomegaly with very high levels of transaminases (>1000 IU/L). Option C: Primary biliary cirrhosis presents with jaundice, severe itching, and pale stools. There 
are high levels of direct bilirubin, ALP, and positive anti-mitochondrial antibodies. System

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following findings would be seen in a patient with Wilson's disease?
questions.explanation:
The following findings will be seen in a patient with Wilson's disease: • Decreased total serum copper • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin • Increased urinary copper Normally, >90% of copper exists in bound form and <10% in free form. In Wilson’s disease, 
despite elevated levels of free copper, the marked reduction in ceruloplasmin results in a net 
reduction of total serum copper i.e., total serum copper =free copper + ceruloplasmin Lab markers

questions.question:
Question 13: A 15-year-old boy is brought with complaints of abnormal posture. His scholastic 
performance used to be above average but has deteriorated over the last 3 months. Dystonia 
and increased muscle tone are noted on clinical examination. The following picture is seen on 
ophthalmic examination. What is the gold standard for the diagnosis of this condition? 318 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario and image showing Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring with sunflower cataract are 
suggestive of Wilson's disease. The gold standard for diagnosis is the estimation of liver 
copper following biopsy. A copper level of >200 g/g dry liver tissue is diagnostic for Wilson's disease. It is measured 
using neutron activation analysis or atomic absorption spectrometry. Sunflower cataract is a rare finding of Wilson’s disease. It occurs due to the deposition of copper 
in the center of the lens.

questions.question:
Question 14: A pathologist is preparing a tissue sample from the liver biopsy of a patient with Wilson's 
disease. What stain will he use?
questions.explanation:
In Wilson’s disease, liver biopsy samples are stained using rubeanic acid to visualize 
the cytoplasmic copper. Another stain used for copper is the rhodanine stain. However, copper staining is not reliable for 
diagnosis and a quantitative copper assay must be performed. The given image shows the staining of copper by rubeanic acid.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 17-year-old girl was brought with involuntary, writhing movements of her limbs. On 
examination, she is anicteric with dystonia and hyperreflexia. Investigations revealed mildly 
elevated transaminases and low serum ceruloplasmin levels. Which of the following is the 
safest drug that can be initiated for this patient?
questions.explanation:
327 
Sold by @itachibot This clinical scenario is suggestive of Wilson's disease with predominantly neurological features. 
The safest drug that can be initiated for this patient is trientine. This is because D-penicillamine 
can worsen neurological symptoms and would not be tolerated by this patient. The copper chelating agents, D-penicillamine and trientine are the first-line drugs in the 
management of Wilson's disease. D-penicillamine is the recommended drug due to its availability 
and cost-effectiveness compared to trientine. However, D-penicillamine can precipitate various adverse effects including aplastic anemia, 
myasthenia gravis and membranous nephropathy. It can also worsen neurological symptoms. 
Hence, trientine is administered in those who cannot tolerate D-penicillamine. Elemental zinc is commonly used as a maintenance therapy along with chelating agents. It can 
also be used as first-line therapy in pregnancy. Tetrathiomolybdate is currently under phase 2 clinical trials. It has been identified to be effective 
in patients with neuropsychiatric manifestations but is not approved for clinical use. Liver transplantation is the definitive treatment for advanced liver disease.

questions.question:
Question 16: For a patient with Wilson's disease, you would administer pyridoxine along with which of the 
following drugs?
questions.explanation:
Penicillamine should always be co-administered with pyridoxine (25 mg/day) as it is an antagonist 
to pyridoxine.

questions.question:
Question 17: The Nazer’s prognostic index for Wilson’s disease includes all of the following parameters 
except:
questions.explanation:
ALT is not a part of Nazer’s prognostic index. Nazer’s prognostic index is used to establish disease severity in Wilson’s disease patients who 
present with hepatic decompensation.

questions.question: Question 18: Low serum copper levels attributed to ATP7A gene is due to:

options.a: Occurs due to alterations in the metabolism of estrogen
options.b: Presence of even 1 lesion is abnormal
options.c: Commonly seen over the superior vena cava territory
options.d: Compression results in blanching followed by reappearance after release

questions.explanation:
Low serum copper level attributed to the ATP7A gene is due to Menke's disease (Option C). Menke's disease or Menke-Kinky hair syndrome is an X-linked recessive condition occurring due 
to a mutation in the ATP7A gene on chromosome X. This causes impaired transport of dietary 
copper from the small intestine to the liver leading to low levels of copper-containing enzymes. It 
presents within 3 years of age and is characterized by: • Depigmented kinky hair • Failure to thrive • Neurodegenerative symptoms like loss of developmental milestones, truncal hypotonia, 
epilepsyLoose, wrinkled skin • Multiple fractures 328 
Sold by @itachibot • Poor visual acuity • Recurrent infections. Lab investigations show low serum copper (<65 g/dL) and low ceruloplasmin(<20 mg/dl). 
The disease is fatal as it has no curative treatment. But, administration of L-histidine and copper 
chloride injections may be beneficial, if started early. Aceruloplasminemia is an autosomal recessive disease characterized by tissue iron overload, 
mental deterioration, microcytic anemia, and low serum iron and copper concentrations. Option B: Low serum copper and low ceruloplasmin is also seen in Wilson’s disease, but is 
associated with the gene defect ATP7B on chromosome 13. It is an autosomal recessive disorder of 
copper metabolism with features of hepatolenticular degeneration and Kayser Fleischer ring. Option A: Dubin Johnson Syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by impaired 
canalicular excretion of bilirubin due to mutation in MRP-2 protein leading to conjugated 
hyperbilirubinemia. Option D: Gilbert’s Syndrome is characterized by decreased UDP glucuronyl transferase activity 
leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which can be autosomal recessive or dominant. 329 
Sold by @itachibot Cirrhosis and Complications
